repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Rural Primary Education
            Management, and Basic Education Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit differs from the
            Implementation Completion Report's (ICR) ratings
            regarding the Rural Primary Education Management Project, in
            that project outcomes are downgraded from satisfactory to
            unsatisfactory, and likewise regarding Bank and Borrower
            performance ratings; yet, sustainability is upgraded to
            likely, while institutional development impacts remain as
            modest. Conversely, on assessing the Basic Education Project
            (PROMEB), the audit concurs with the ICR's ratings of
            satisfactory outcomes, substantial institutional development
            impacts, likely sustainability, and satisfactory Bank and
            Borrower performances. Experience with the assessed
            projects, confirm a number of the Operations Evaluation
            Department - OED - lessons in the education sector: Despite
            considerable quality-oriented investments by both the
            assessed projects, progress in student performance has been
            limited, confirming that educational project inputs, and
            rising education budgets do not translate automatically into
            increased student performance; rather, to increase
            performance, teachers and students must use inputs
            effectively, maximizing the instructional time students are
            engaged in learning. While both assessed projects developed
            action plans, their implementation was limited. Such actions
            must be feasible within the budget, and human resources
            available, and, Government officials must also clearly
            perceive the need for plans, and the subsequent actions.
            Notwithstanding, the PROMEB and its follow-up project
            successfully involved the communities in the management of
            rural schools, which suggests that decentralization of
            school management to the community level, may mobilize local
            support for the schools, thus increasing pride in
            achievement by students, and teachers. However, although the
            achievement tests developed through PROMEB provided valuable
            monitoring information to the government, such outcomes were
            not widely disseminated, and its use was limited: to be
            valuable, however, the information must be disseminated
            widely at the school level if possible, and actions must be
            carried out based on the feedback it provides.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Rural Primary Education
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Rural Primary Education Management
            Project (ADEPRIR) in Honduras. The specific objectives were
            to (a) enhance the institutional capacity of SEP in the
            areas of inter-ministerial coordination, sector policy
            formulation, planning of education development, allocation
            of expenditures (including coordination of development
            assistance), and internal administration; and (b) assist the
            Govemment to prepare and test an effective system for
            administering rural primary schools, which would economize
            on recurrent expenditures, improve cost-effectiveness, and
            establish the basis for raising student achievement. Some
            lessons learned included: Government policy changes and
            original project objectives do not coincide. Project success
            and ultimate sustainability require that during
            implementation top-level ministerial authorities closely
            monitor and provide support, and coordinate with other
            sector development projects. The innovative rural primary
            school management network scheme appears to viable, worth
            strengthening and expanding. Close coordination among donor
            agencies is needed in part to ensure that project management
            capacity not be overloaded. The Staff Appraisal Report (SAR)
            pointed out that the major risk was State Secretariat of
            Public Education (SEP's) limited managerial capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Rural Primary Education
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Primary Education Management
            Project for Honduras is part of a phased approach to support
            the Government's efforts to improve the quality and
            effectiveness of education while economizing on
            expenditures.  It seeks to alleviate key constraints to the
            Ministry of Public Education's (SEP) capacity to
            effectively plan and carry out needed investments and
            administer the educational system.  On this basis, the
            project seeks to strengthen the structure and management
            capacity of SEP and to decentralize the management of rural
            primary education.  To this end, the Rural Primary Education
            Management Project for Honduras aims to enhance the
            management capacity and performance of SEP through technical
            assistance.  It also seeks to assist SEP in developing and
            testing an effective management and development planning
            system for rural primary education which is designed to
            economize on expenditures, improve cost-effectiveness and
            establish the basis for raising student achievement.  In
            line with this, the project provides technical assistance
            and a micro-planning effort for rural schools in the project area.
